And now we are on
to the last topic,

which has to do with
the sampling approach.

And sampling approaches are a
really, really powerful tool

that gives us a way to
conduct hypothesis testing,

either a single
hypothesis test or a lot

of hypothesis tests in a way
that's relatively assumption
free.
So what is this all about?

Well, in this
lecture so far, we've

assumed that we're in this
scenario where we want to test
some null hypothesis H0.

We have a test statistic T,
and most importantly, we know

or else we feel like we can
assume the distribution of T
under the null hypothesis.

And that's how we were able
to compute the P value was

by knowing the distribution
of the test statistic
under the null hypothesis.

So remember this
figure from before.

And the distribution of T
under the null hypothesis
was this yellow curve.

In this particular example, the
distribution of T under the null

was a approximately a
normal distribution.

But in general, depending
on your null hypothesis,

depending on your T statistic,
that null distribution

of the test statistic could
be a different distribution.
An unknown, or--
It could be unknown.

And, in fact, that's
the idea, here

is what if this theoretical
null distribution is actually
unknown.

We just don't know
what it looks like.

Or alternatively, we could make
some assumptions under which we

might know what it
looks like, but maybe we

feel a little bit weird
making those assumptions

because we don't really
think they're going to hold.

Or we're worried they
might not hold, at least.

We're worried they
might not hold.

We just want to do something
that's a little bit
more assumption-free.

So one way we can
do this is using
a resampling type of approach.

And the thing we should say
about sampling approaches

before we get into the
details is that it's

a very general framework
that needs to be instantiated

in a specific way, depending
on the type of hypothesis

you're testing and the type of
test statistic you're using.

So today we're going to
talk about what a sampling

approach will look like for
conducting a two sample t-test.

But, in general, if you're
testing a different type

of null hypothesis, it's not
just the difference in means
or if you have a test statistic.

That's not just a
two sample T test,

you're going to
need to figure out

whether there is an appropriate
sampling approach for you,

and also what that sampling
approach looks like.

So this is going to really
require some hard thinking

and it's not plug
and play, the way

that a lot of things that we've
seen so far in this lecture are.

So the idea is
suppose that we want

to test the null hypothesis
that the mean in one group

equals the mean in another
group versus the alternative
that they're unequal.

And here we have n sub x,
independent observations from X

and n sub Y independent
observations from Y.

Well then as we've
already seen today,

the two sample T,
statistic takes

the form of just the sample
mean in group X minus the sample

mean in group Y
divided by an estimate

of the standard deviation
between mu X minus mu Y.

And if nX and nY are large,
then as we've already said,

T approximately
follows a normal 0,

1 distribution under
the null hypothesis.

But what happens if an
nX and nY are small?

Well, in that case,
we actually don't

know the theoretical
null distribution of T,

unless we make
further assumptions

about the distribution
of the data.

The distribution of
the Xs and the Ys.

So what we can do is we can try
to take a sampling approach.

And the idea behind
a sampling approach

is that instead of just like
looking up in a textbook

what the theoretical
null distribution of T is

or taking our word for it or
deriving it yourself, if that's

your thing, we're
actually just going

to let a computer
simulate for us what

the null distribution of T
would look like under the null
hypothesis.
